member.name: T:PhyloTree.AttributeDictionary
member.summary: Represents the attributes of a node. Attributes , and are always included. See the respective properties for default values.

member.name: P:PhyloTree.AttributeDictionary.Name
member.summary: The name of this node (e.g. the species name for leaf nodes). Default is "". Getting the value of this property does not require a dictionary lookup.

member.name: P:PhyloTree.AttributeDictionary.Length
member.summary: The length of the branch leading to this node. This is double.NaN for branches whose length is not specified (e.g. the root node). Getting the value of this property does not require a dictionary lookup.

member.name: P:PhyloTree.AttributeDictionary.Support
member.summary: The support value of this node. This is double.NaN for branches whose support is not specified. The interpretation of the support value depends on how the tree was built. Getting the value of this property does not require a dictionary lookup.

member.name: M:PhyloTree.Formats.BinaryExtensions.ReadShortInt(System.IO.BinaryReader,System.Byte@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Read a variable-width integer from the stream. If the integer is equal to 0, 2 or 3, it is 2-bit wide; if it is 1, 4 or 5, it is 4-bit wide; if it is greater than 5, the current byte is padded and the integer is represented as an integer of the format read by in the following byte(s). The initial value of currByte should be read using and the initial value of currIndex should be 0. Successive reads should use the same variables, which will have been updated by this method. After the last read, if *currIndex is equal to 0, it means that currByte has not been processed (thus you should seek back by 1).
member.param: The from which to read.
The current byte that is being read
The current index within the byte.
member.returns: The value read.

member.name: M:PhyloTree.Formats.BinaryExtensions.WriteShortInt(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Int32,System.Byte@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write a variable-width integer from the stream. If the integer is equal to 0, 2 or 3, it is 2-bit wide; if it is 1, 4 or 5, it is 4-bit wide; if it is greater than 5, the current byte is padded and the integer is represented as an integer of the format written by readInt in the following byte(s). The initial value of currByte and currIndex should be 0. Successive writes should use the same variables, which will have been updated by this method. After the last write, if *currIndex is not 0, it means that the current byte has not been written to the stream yet.
member.param: The on which to write.
The value to be written.
The value of the byte that is being written.
The current index within the byte.

member.name: T:PhyloTree.Formats.NcbiAsnBer

Contains methods to read and write trees in the NCBI ASN.1 binary format.
Note: this is a hackish reverse-engineering of the NCBI binary ASN format. A lot of this is derived by assumptions and observations.

If is false, this determines whether the names of the nodes are placed between single quotes.

member.name: M:PhyloTree.Extensions.TypeExtensions.GetConsensus(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{PhyloTree.TreeNode},System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Action{System.Double},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a consensus tree.
member.param: The collection of trees whose consensus is to be computed.
Whether the consensus tree should be rooted or not.
Whether the trees are to be treated as clock-like trees or not. This has an effect on how the branch lengths of the consensus tree are computed.
The (inclusive) threshold for splits to be included in the consensus tree. Use 0 to get all compatible splits, 0.5 for a majority-rule consensus or 1 for a strict consensus.
If this is true, the lengths of the branches in the tree will be computed based on the median length/age of the splits used to build the tree. Otherwise, the mean will be used.
An that will be invoked as the trees are processed.

If this is true, parts of the consensus computation will be parallelised. This will, however, increase the number of computations that need to be performed. The advantages will differ based on the number of trees, how discordant they are, and the characteristics of the processor.
member.returns: A rooted consensus tree.

member.name: M:PhyloTree.SequenceScores.ParsimonyScore.GetParsimonyScore(PhyloTree.TreeNode,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Char})
member.summary: Computes the parsimony score (minimum number of state changes) for a character on a tree.
member.param: The tree for which the parsimony score is computed.
The character states at the tips of the tree. This should contain an entry for each terminal node of the tree, where the key is either the or and the value is the character state.
member.returns: The parsimony score (minimum number of state changes) for the specified character.
member.exception: Thrown when the dictionary does not contain an entry for one of the tips in the tree.
member.remarks: The character states can be anything; the only thing that is taken into account when computing parsimony score is whether two states are the same or not. Note that this is case sensitive.

member.name: M:PhyloTree.SequenceScores.ParsimonyScore.GetSankoffParsimonyScore(PhyloTree.TreeNode,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Char},System.Char[],System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: Computes the Sankoff parsimony score for a character on a tree.
member.param: The tree for which the parsimony score is computed.
The character states at the tips of the tree. This should contain an entry for each terminal node of the tree, where the key is either the or and the value is the character state.
The character states.
The transition cost matrix. Indices in this matrix should correspond to the states in the array.
member.returns: The Sankoff parsimony score for the specified character.
member.exception: Thrown when the dictionary does not contain an entry for one of the tips in the tree.
member.remarks: Note that diagonal entries in the cost matrix may not be 0, in which case even retaining the same state across a branch will incur a cost. This may or may not be useful.

member.summary: Simulates the evolution of the sequence over a phylogenetic , with the specified rate matrix, factor, and insertion/deletion model.
member.param: The tree over which the sequence evolves. This is assumed to be rooted (i.e., the ancestral sequence is placed at the root of the tree).
The rate matrix that governs the evolution of the sequence.
A scaling factor. If this is different from 1, the effect is the same as multiplying the branch lengths of the tree or the rate matrix by the supplied value.
The model for insertions/deletions. If this is null, no insertions/deletions are allowed to happen.
member.returns: A containing entries for all the nodes in the tree that have names. For each entry, the key is a containing the of the node, and the value is a containing the sequence. The sequences are all aligned.

A scaling factor. If this is different from 1, the effect is the same as multiplying the branch lengths of the tree or the rate matrix by the supplied value.
The model for insertions/deletions. If this is null, no insertions/deletions are allowed to happen.

member.param: The names for the terminal nodes of the tree. Note that, if is , the actual number of leaves in the tree may be larger than this, because the leaves corresponding to dead lineages are kept (their names will be empty). If all the lineages go extinct before the target number of lineages is reaced, the method will return a smaller tree (without any leaf names) if is , or if it is .
The birth rate of the tree.
The death rate of the tree.
If this is , dead lineages are kept in the tree. If this is , they are pruned from the tree.

A tree to constrain the sampling. The tree produced by this method will be compatible with this tree. The constraint tree can be multifurcating. Please note that, as the constraint is applied at every step while growing the tree, this will bias the sampled topology distribution.
A used to cancel the simulation if it takes too long.
member.returns: A object containing the unlabelled birth-death tree, or if all the lineages went extinct and is .

member.name: T:PhyloTree.TreeBuilding.EvolutionModel
member.summary: The sequence evolution model used to compute the distance matrix from the alignment.

member.name: F:PhyloTree.TreeBuilding.EvolutionModel.Hamming
member.summary: Normalised Hamming distance (proportion of different nucleotides/amino acids).

member.name: F:PhyloTree.TreeBuilding.EvolutionModel.JukesCantor
member.summary: Jukes-Cantor model (assuming equal nucleotide/amino acid frequencies and substitution rates).

member.name: F:PhyloTree.TreeBuilding.EvolutionModel.Kimura
member.summary: For DNA alignments, this represents the Kimura 1980 model (assuming equal base frequencies, and unequal transition/transversion rates). For protein alignments, this represents the Kimura 1983 model that approximates PAM distances based only on the fraction of differing amino acids.

member.name: F:PhyloTree.TreeBuilding.EvolutionModel.GTR
member.summary: Only applicable for DNA alignments. This represents the GTR distance, computed as in Waddell & Steel, 1997 (doi: 10.1006/mpev.1997.0452). Note that since this process involves matrix diagonalisation, it is about an order of magnitude slower than other distance metrics.

member.name: F:PhyloTree.TreeBuilding.EvolutionModel.BLOSUM62
member.summary: Only applicable for Protein alignments. This represents a distance computed using the Scoredist algorithm with the BLOSUM62 matrix, as in Sonnhammer & Hollich, 2005 (doi: 10.1186/1471-2105-6-108). Note that in this case U, O and J are treated as gaps.

member.name: M:PhyloTree.TreeBuilding.DistanceMatrix.ConvertProteinSequence(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a protein sequence stored as a string into a array. Each ushort contains 2 amino acid positions. The allowed symbols are the usual 20 1-letter amino acid abbreviations, plus U for Sec, O for Pyl, B for Asn or Asp, Z for Gln or Glu, J for Ile or Leu, X for any amino acid, * for stop codons and - for gaps (uppercase and lowercase). All other characters are treated as gaps. If the sequence length is not a multiple of 2, it is padded with gaps.
member.param: The sequence to convert.
member.returns: A array representing the sequence.

member.summary: Builds a neighbour-joining tree using data from a sequence alignment. This method first computes a distance matrix from the sequence alignment, and then uses the distance matrix to compute the tree.
member.param: The sequence alignment.
The evolutionary model to use when computing the distance matrix.
The number of bootstrap replicates to perform.
The type of sequence alignment (DNA, protein, or autodetect).
An optional tree to constrain the search. The tree produced by this method will be compatible with this tree. The constraint tree can be multifurcating.
If this is negative branches produced by the neighbour-joining algorithm are left untouched; otherwise, their (absolute) length is added to the sibling branch, and the negative length is set to 0.
Maximum number of threads to use, or -1 to let the runtime decide.
A method used to report progress.
member.returns: The neighbour-joining tree built from the supplied .

member.name: M:PhyloTree.TreeBuilding.NeighborJoining.BuildTree(System.Single[][],System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{System.String},PhyloTree.TreeNode,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Action{System.Double})
member.summary: Builds a neighbour-joining tree using data from a distance matrix.
member.param: The distance matrix containg distances between the taxa. This can be a lower triangular matrix or a full matrix; values above the diagonal will not be used.
The names of the taxa. The indices of this list should correspond to the rows and columns of the .
An optional tree to constrain the search. The tree produced by this method will be compatible with this tree. The constraint tree can be multifurcating.

If this is , the matrix is copied before using it to compute the tree. If this is , the matrix is not copied. Copying the matrix increases the memory used by the method, but note that if the matrix is not copied, it will be modified in-place!
If this is negative branches produced by the neighbour-joining algorithm are left untouched; otherwise, their (absolute) length is added to the sibling branch, and the negative length is set to 0.
Maximum number of threads to use, or -1 to let the runtime decide.
A method used to report progress.
member.returns: The neighbour-joining tree built from the supplied .

member.name: T:PhyloTree.TreeCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of objects. If the full representations of the objects reside in memory, this offers the best performance at the expense of memory usage. Alternatively, the trees may be read on demand from a stream in binary format. In this case, accessing any of the trees will require the tree to be parsed. This reduces memory usage, but worsens performance. The internal storage model of the collection is transparent to consumers (except for the difference in performance/memory usage).

member.summary: Computes a distance matrix containing the Robinson-Foulds distances between each pair of trees in a list.
member.param: The list of trees that should be compared.
If this is , the distance is weighted based on the branch lengths; otherwise, it is unweighted.

If this is , all trees are pruned so that they only contain the subset of leaves that are present in all trees. If this is , during each comparisons the two trees are pruned so that they contain the subset of leaves that are in common between both of them.
The maximum number of threads to use for parallelised steps.
An for progress reporting.
member.returns: A square [,] matrix containing the requested distances between the trees.

member.remarks: Note that the node is pruned in-place; however, the return value of this method should be used, because pruning the node may have caused the root of the tree to move.
member.returns: The corresponding to the root of the tree after the current node has been pruned.

member.name: M:PhyloTree.TreeNode.CollessIndex(PhyloTree.TreeNode.NullHypothesis,System.Double)
member.summary: Compute the Colless index of the tree.
member.param: If this is , the raw Colless index is returned. If this is or , the Colless index is normalised with respect to the corresponding null tree model (which makes scores comparable across trees of different sizes).

If is , you can optionally use this parameter to provide a pre-computed value for the expected value of the Colless index under the YHK model. This is useful to save time if you need to compute the Colless index of many trees with the same number of leaves. If this is , the expected value under the YHK model is computed by this method.
member.returns: The Colless index of the tree.

member.returns: The number of cherries in the tree.
